pages.subdeck: Heartbreak ... Mel Vondrau saddened by Tulisa sex tape shock
pages.headline: Tulisa stepmum sex tape shock
pages.teaser: TULISA Contostavlos' stepmum reveals she was 'disgusted and heartbroken' by the X Factor star's XXX vid
pages.articlebody:
TULISA Contostavlos' stepmum last night told how she was disgusted by the X Factor star's sex tape  and declared: "My heart just broke."

Shocked Melanie Vondrau , 39, stormed: "The fact that she would even allow a tape like that to be made just proves she doesn't respect herself."

South African-born Melanie  who was married to the former N-Dubz singer's dad Plato for ten years until their 2009 divorce  said: "I'm appalled. Tulisa doesn't respect herself because of the way she was brought up  especially when it comes to men."

She explained sadly: "A young girl who respects herself would choose her partner very wisely.

"She is clearly not making the right partner choices.

"She is not seeking out a healthy relationship  a genuine and honourable man."

Mel grew close to Tulisa after her real mum Ann had a breakdown when she was just 11.

She fears her stepdaughter, 23, will struggle to live down the tape showing her performing a sex act on then-boyfriend Justin Edwards, 28  a wannabe rap star who calls himself MC Ultra.

Mel went on to blast whoever left Tulisa squirming by posting the footage on the internet.

She said: "I know chances are Tulisa is the victim. But she needs to stop being so careless with herself and her career.

"She is so talented and has the chance to make it big.

"She can't afford for stuff to come out like this."

The stepmum blamed Tulisa's broken home and her subsequent hunt for a father figure for landing herself in trouble. She said:

"She needs strong loving parental guidance. Unfortunately for Tulisa, her mum is not very well and she has got a father who is a distant character.

"I feel she is a victim of her childhood,  the classic little girl who wants her father's love.

"And that is because she's been desperately seeking the love and affection of men since she was a little girl.

"From what I can see  as someone who knows her from childhood  she is searching for someone just like her father.

"She needs to find someone kind, honourable and genuine. A man who comes from a proper family background and has family values."

Mel  now a housewife living in Hertfordshire  described the singer's relationship with her father Plato as stormy. She claimed this did not make for a happy childhood, saying: "All Tulisa wanted was her father's love."

Mel wed Plato in 1999 two years after they met. The couple had moved in together in Queen's Park, North West London.

Describing how Tulisa was sometimes a handful, Mel said:

"When she was young, her role models were Charlie's Angels and the Spice Girls.

"They were all about empowering yourself and girl power. I said to her: 'True girl power is a strong independent woman who really likes and knows who she is.'

"The fans may see this very hardened, tough character who has all the tattoos  but the character that I see is the little girl that I remember."

Mel believes the pressure of being in a band from a young age made Tulisa grow up too quickly.

She said: "She was sexualised from a very young age.

"I used to gasp at some of the things she wore as a girl.

"She had no one to tell her it was inappropriate to wear stomach and cleavage-baring tops when she was just developing.

"She always went for wild guys  the type her father hated."

Tulisa took to YouTube last Wednesday to admit she was the star of the embarrassingly intimate video with ex-boyfriend Justin.

She had earlier denied she was the blonde performing a sex act on him in the six-minute clip.

Mel said of whoever released the tape: "What sort of a guy does that? What you do in the bedroom is private.

"Who has a relationship with you and then does that?"

TV mogul Simon Cowell has insisted the scandal will not cost Tulisa her X Factor job as a judge on the hit ITV1 show.

But her stepmum said: "She is hurting. How can anyone recover from something like this?

"When she meets someone in the future will they think of her as the girl who was in the sex tape?

"I really hope she will learn about her inner strength.

"She has not got to where she is now by being a softie.

"But she has come out of this week and she has put out a video giving her side.

"Not many people would have the guts or strength to do that."

a.crick@the-sun.co.uk

She wants dad's love



TULISA has been seeking love since her troubled childhood and desperately wants a man who will be a father figure to her, stepmum Mel believes.

The series of touching photos below reveal moments in the early life of the girl who was to become a recording and TV star  showing her with dad Plato and N-Dubz bandmates.

pages.subdeck: PUT YER SHIRT ON ME ... Rio is closing in on a new United contract
pages.headline: New deal for Rio
pages.teaser: ALEX FERGUSON reckons Ferdy can play on for years with the right fitness regime
pages.articlebody:
RIO FERDINAND is heading for a new deal at Old Trafford.

The Manchester United defender's deal finishes next season but boss Alex Ferguson believes that with the right fitness regime he can play on for years.

Ferdinand's current deal is worth £120,000 a week but the 33-year-old's new one may include a reduced basic with bonuses for playing.

Fergie said: "Rio's still young for a centre-back. I think it's all down to how he feels physically and what he is doing at the moment is good. He has no issues at all.

"I think from time to time he gets the odd tweak in his back and we have to manage it and look after it.

"He's adapting really well to the challenge of making sure he is fit and fresh to play in the games where we need him."

Ferguson  who already has golden oldies Paul Scholes, 37, and Ryan Giggs, 38, in his squad  made it clear earlier in the season Ferdinand has had to adapt his game due to a loss of pace.

But the United boss believes the player's injury problems have in no way affected his influence on the club's younger stars.

Fergie added: "I keep thinking I signed Rio three or four years ago. I forget he's been here for almost 10 years.

"He has taken on the role of the influential person in the dressing room.

"He's great with the other players, he's simply brilliant."

Ferdinand will be at the heart of the United defence again tonight as the Red Devils take on Fulham looking to regain top spot from rivals Manchester City.

Read more: Man Utd v Fulham team news

pages.subdeck: CRACKING UP ... Roberto Mancini
pages.headline: Rob tickler
pages.teaser: AND Mancini's No2 David Platt insists the City boss is not cracking under the strain
pages.articlebody:
ROBERTO MANCINI laughed off Alex Ferguson's attempts at playing mind games.

And Mancini's No 2 David Platt insists the Manchester City boss is not cracking under the strain of the two-horse race for the Premier League title.

Manchester United boss Fergie labelled rival Mancini desperate on Friday for allowing Carlos Tevez back in his squad.

But Platt, 45, said: "Robbie just laughed, it's not a problem to him.

"It's not about him and it's not about Sir Alex. It's about the two teams."

United can go three points clear tonight by beating Fulham after City were held 1-1 at Stoke on Saturday.

Mancini, 47, refused to shake Potters boss Tony Pulis' hand or speak to the press.

The Etihad chief was angry at the lack of protection his players received in the face of Stoke's physical approach.

But Platt says his reaction was simply a reflection of his desire to deliver City's first league title since 1968.

Platt added: "He wants to win. He is intense.

"It's not about whether he handles the pressure so much as it's about whether the players go out and get the results.

"He's fine. He's beyond fine. Seriously!

"He just has a great deal of belief, a great deal of positivity about him.

"His standards are high but the players have stepped up to that this season."

City have conceded the advantage in the title race after winning just one of their last three games in the league.

But with eight games left and the Manc derby to come at the Etihad on April 30, Platt remains positive.

He said: "You have to take this season as a whole. We've got 70 points from 30 games and there are eight left.

"We don't take an individual game or say we've done well in the last two. It's irrelevant whether we've done well or poorly in the last two.

"What is relevant is we are still in with a very good chance with eight games left.

"Going top is obviously a bonus. But you have to expect United will win quite a few games before the end of the season.

"Equally we expect to win quite a few, too, and I believe it's going to go very, very close. I've believed that for a long time.

"People can talk about the title race but everyone has to say that two teams have had exceptional seasons."

pages.subdeck: HE KEN DO IT ... Kenny Dalglish
pages.headline: Kenny is not a man who's lost touch with football
pages.teaser: THE ALARM bells are ringing at Anfield after the collapse at Loftus Road was followed by defeat at home to Wigan this weekend
pages.articlebody:
THE ALARM bells are ringing at Anfield after the collapse at Loftus Road was followed by defeat at home to Wigan this weekend.

A glance at the league table and Liverpool are as far away from Champions League football now as they were when Kenny Dalglish returned.

A top-four finish had to be the target this season after a £113million outlay on the team.

But 13 points now divides Liverpool from Tottenham who hold that final Champions League place at the moment.

A tilt at the title can only be but a distant dream  long into the distance at that.

My Match of the Day colleague Lee Dixon informed us on Saturday that just five home wins from 15 is their worst tally since 1953.

Quite how he knew that is anyone's guess, clever guy Lee.

You look at the buys and you have to say both Andy Carroll and Stewart Downing have flopped.

I, for one, didn't think they would.

Carroll can't have lost the ability overnight that made him such a good player at Newcastle.

It did seem an awful lot of money but as I know, the player himself cannot control that, although he does have to cope with the extra burden that brings.

It is a burden that at times looks to have weighed Carroll down, although if someone like Downing had actually been able to find him with a few crosses I'm sure things could have been different.

Jordan Henderson hasn't done it, Charlie Adam is in and out.

But both Luis Suarez and Jose Enrique have proved to be good buys.

Suarez might need too many chances to get his goal but his all-round play has undoubtedly been one of the few pluses.

Yet do you know that in terms of silverware this could yet be Liverpool's best season in 11 years.

If they add the FA Cup to the Carling Cup, which is a very real possibility, there will be envious glances from everyone bar the Premier League champions themselves.

That is why, right now, any criticism of Dalglish should be tempered. There is no doubt the league campaign has simply not been good enough  but the cups could provide salvation.

They desperately need the FA Cup to ensure that. If not what do you do, get rid of Dalglish?

The criticism some would have is that he has been out the game too long and lost touch.

I have worked under him at both Blackburn and Newcastle and, believe me, this is a man who would not lose touch with the game if he was on the moon.

He studies it whether in it or out, if there is a park game going on around the corner he would watch.

This is not a man who has lost touch with football.

And I doubt either he has lost the techniques that made little Blackburn take on the big boys and win the 1995 title.

He was a master at Blackburn, invoking a togetherness and desire to achieve unlike any I have known.

I don't believe he has lost that ability.

Just 13 months is no time to make a club like Liverpool great again. And yet a cup double this season and he will have taken some big steps on the road to achieving that.

A long-term plan, after all, and success in whatever form it comes breeds confidence.

Liverpool fans and the owner should keep faith.

The right man is still at the helm, he just needs more time.

Classy Coyle

BOLTON and their manager Owen Coyle have come out of the last fortnight with enormous credit.

Coyle, his chairman, players and fans have all shown what a real football club they are.

And not only in the way they have handled the tragic circumstances of Patrice Muamba's near-fatal heart attack.

They had to get back and play a football match too. Lesser men may have crumbled under the weight of emotion on Saturday, yet they used it as a powerful force to win.

Bolton stood up and put on an occasion and performance to be remembered as they beat fellow-strugglers Blackburn to give them new hope of staying up.

And after everything that has happened, I sincerely hope they do.

You got off lightly Rob

I AM not sure what Manchester City boss Roberto Mancini had to moan about at Stoke.

Yes the Potters are physical, yes they get about you, and yes they ask you questions. You just have to find the answers.

I don't think there was any intention in Dean Whitehead's challenge on David Silva that left him needing a bandage.

But I do believe Stoke should have had a penalty when Gareth Barry brought down Glenn Whelan.

I can understand Mancini's frustration at failing to win but he should not be looking at Stoke when trying to find someone to blame.

pages.subdeck: EYES ON THE PRIZE ... Petr Cech wants top-four finish
pages.headline: We can't Cech out
pages.teaser: KEEPER says Blues will have "lost a year" if they fail to qualify for next season's tournament
pages.articlebody:
PETR CECH says Chelsea will have 'lost a year' if they fail to qualify for next season's Champions League.

The Blues have two chances of making it  either by finishing in the top four of the Premier League or by winning Europe's biggest prize this season.

After Saturday's goalless draw at home to Spurs, they remain five points behind the North Londoners in the race for fourth place with only eight games left.

Newcastle also drew level with the Blues after their win at West Brom yesterday.

Chelsea are confident of getting through their Champions League quarter-final against Benfica  with the first leg in Lisbon tomorrow night.

But they are then likely to face holders  and hot favourites  Barcelona in the last four.

And asked what missing out on competing in the Champions League would mean to Chelsea, Cech replied: "It is a year lost in the progression of the club.

"You always have years when you go through transition and the team needs to be rebuilt.

"Or you have changes in terms of managers and players.

"For a big club, you can accept that the team does not win the league because it is in transition.

"But you can't afford to slip out of the Champions League because that is what the big teams are about.

"The importance of it is clear, it is much better than the Europa League.

"We want to make sure that we will be there next season, somehow.

"But we have put ourselves in a position in the Premier League where it is not in our hands."

Liverpool proved how difficult it is to win a seat back at Europe's top table once you slip out of the reckoning. Cech, 29, said: "Liverpool had so many problems within the club, not really on the pitch, so that is why they lost some time. But this club has the structure.

"I do believe that one season will make a difference, because it will slow down all the process of being a Champions League club and hunting for trophies.

"But it will not be the end of Chelsea because I believe that we will come back."

Roberto Di Matteo's side have the heaviest fixture list of any English team with their European matches and an FA Cup semi-final coming on top of the Premier League games.

Cech added: "If we manage to get through to the semi-final of the Champions League, we will have a crazy calendar with a lot of games.

"With the FA Cup as well, it's good in a way because it means that you are in the hunt for trophies.

"But in terms of the Premier League, we have put ourselves in a difficult position.

"But there are 24 points still left and that is a lot of points to play for. In that period you could overcome a five-point deficit.

"You need to make sure that you win all your games or the majority of them and the other teams slip up.

"Spurs was an opportunity missed for us. It was a head-to-head game and a chance to close the gap and we didn't do that."

Striker Didier Drogba feels Chelsea have only themselves to blame for their predicament in the Premier League.

He said: "If Spurs and Arsenal are above us, in these positions, it's because they deserve it.

"We haven't done anything to be above them, let's be honest. But there are still enough games to change this."

Right now, Drogba has his sights firmly fixed on Benfica.

And he still feels inspired by the way the Blues overturned a 3-1 first-leg deficit to beat Napoli with that stirring second-leg performance.

The 4-1 win, after extra-time, means Blues fans can dream of another stunning semi-final clash with Barcelona.

Drogba said: "Football! Football and Chelsea  that's what it was.

"There are teams who you know can do it, whatever the challenge  even if they lost by five or six away.

"There are a few teams that you know can do it in those situations and Chelsea is one of them.

"With the players we have and the mentality we have here to fight  and fight until the last minute  we can do anything.

"I believe that's why we've had these moments in so many seasons, because we all believe we can do it and when we do something, we do it as a team, as a group.

"We have started to believe a bit more in ourselves and there is a little bit more confidence now.

"The only thing that can change a dressing room is winning games and going on a good run of results.

"Even if you have the best atmosphere in the dressing room to begin with, when you lose games everyone will be down. That's just human.

"However, when you win games, everything is better.

"Now we want to win again and give ourselves confidence for the coming weeks."

Centre-back Gary Cahill joined in January for £7million from Bolton.

And having tasted the Champions League for the first time, he is desperate to qualify again next term.

Cahill said: "Obviously, we've got to win the majority of the games we've got left and we've got some tough games coming up. But that's our target."

pages.subdeck: SUPPORT ... Bolton's players warmed up for their clash with Blackburn wearing Fabrice Muamba shirts
pages.headline: Muamba watches Match of the Day
pages.teaser: FABRICE MUAMBA continued his recovery this weekend  by watching Bolton on Match of the Day!
pages.articlebody:
FABRICE MUAMBA continued his recovery this weekend  by watching Bolton on Match of the Day!

The Trotters midfielder collapse just over a week ago during an FA Cup clash with Tottenham at White Hart Lane.

He is still hospitalised in intensive care at an East London hospital but his progress has been good.

And on Sunday morning he was able to watch highlights of his team-mates' 2-1 win over Blackburn.

Bolton boss Owen Coyle said: "Fabrice is able to recognise people and answer questions.

"He also watched Match of the Day on Sunday morning, which shows he is making progress, although he did fall asleep with the score at 2-0."

Coyle also confirmed some Bolton players will visit Muamba ahead of tomorrow's rearranged quarter-final at Spurs.

Ahead of the match, the Scot added: "It will give us a chance to thank the Tottenham fans.

"Last Saturday it was almost like a sixth sense had taken over.

"There was a real sense of unity. Is it going to be tough? Yes."

By dozing off, Muamba missed Steven Nzonzi's goal for Blackburn.

That was not enough to prevent Bolton securing a victory that allowed them to clamber out of the relegation zone.

Coyle said: "Fabrice's father, Marcel, and fiancee, Shauna, wanted to express their thanks to everyone.

"Football is a passionate game but nothing is more important than Fabrice's recovery."

Spurs have revealed that shirts worn by both teams for the replay will be signed and auctioned for charity.

The proceeds going to the London Chest Hospital, the London Ambulance Service, the British Heart Foundation, Pan Africa Heart Foundation and C.R.Y. (Cardiac Risk in the Young).

pages.subdeck: FLETCHER SKETCH ... Darren is drawing up recover plans
pages.headline: Fletch has stomach for fight
pages.teaser: SCOT is suffering from a bowel disease and has not played since November
pages.articlebody:
DARREN FLETCHER has vowed to come back fitter and stronger from his illness nightmare.

The Manchester United star is suffering from an inflammatory bowel disease and has not played since November.

Fletcher, 27, is yet to even return to training.

The midfielder said: "I'm still not ready to come back playing or training yet but I'm listening to the medical people and trying to get myself right.

"The challenge and the focus is to be ready for next season.

"Me and the medical team decided it'd be best if I tried to get myself right and take an extended period out from the game; then come back fully fit and ready to play."

Fletcher has taken over some of Paul Scholes' coaching duties that were freed up when the veteran came out of retirement.

And the Scot added: "It's an unpredictable illness and you don't know what lies ahead of you.

"But I've got to keep staying strong and keep believing. That's an important side of it: positive thinking.

"I've received great support from everyone in Scotland and down in Manchester. I'm hopeful and really positive that I'll be back and back to my best."

pages.subdeck: MASTER BATSMAN ... Mahela Jayawardene reaches his century
pages.headline: Jayawardene century lights up day one
pages.teaser: JAMES ANDERSON took three wickets but master batsman took Sri Lanka to 289-8
pages.articlebody:
MAHELA JAYAWARDENE struck a sensational century as battling England were pushed hard on day one of the First Test with Sri Lanka.

The hosts reached 289-8 at stumps, with their captain and master batsman Jayawardene ending up 168 not out having been dropped FOUR times.

But after losing the toss and fielding in searing heat in Galle, England skipper Andrew Strauss will be pleased to see his attack winkle out eight wickets on a ground famed for big scores.

James Anderson has figures of 3-56, with Test debutant Samit Patel taking 2-27 with his left-arm spin.

Fellow twirler Monty Panesar had a shocker in the field however, twice dropping Jayawardene late in the day's play.

England would surely have batted first had Strauss won the toss but their opening bowlers were quick to banish such thoughts.

Anderson had an lbw appeal against Lahiru Thirimanne rejected from the sixth ball of the day  a decision England wastefully reviewed  and then had him caught at second slip in the third over.

That wicket was Anderson's 250th Test scalp and he celebrated in stunning fashion by removing key man Kumar Sangakkara for a golden duck with his next ball.

Sangakkara fenced at one he could have left, feeding wicketkeeper Matt Prior the simplest of catches.

By the time Tillakaratne Dilshan (11) nicked Stuart Broad to first slip, the score was 15 -3.

But Jayawardene and Thilan Samaraweera inched their side to 66 for three at lunch but a slice of luck allowed England to strike early in the afternoon session.

Anderson got a fingertip to Jayawardene's straight drive, doing enough to part the stumps and leave Samaraweera run out for 20 at the non-striker's end.

New man Dinesh Chandimal, in his first home Test, got off the mark with a flat six off Panesar and clubbed a second maximum off Patel.

But the Nottinghamshire man got his own back when Chandimal fell for 27, mis-hitting an ugly swipe to Ian Bell at cover for Patel's first Test scalp.

All the while Jayawardene was progressing serenely, passing 50 with a punchy drive off Panesar.

Prasanna Jayawardene joined his namesake at the crease but, after starting with some positive shots off Swann, became Anderson's third victim five balls after tea.

The seamer won a borderline lbw, before Strauss produced a superb pick up and throw to run out Suraj Randiv for 12 amd see Sri Lanka 191-7.

Jayawardene offered a first real chance on 90 when Anderson failed to grasp a return catch.

He did not waste his life, flaying the seamer's next attempt for six and paddling Swann for four to bring up his century in 200 balls.

No9 Rangana Herath offering solid support before falling to lbw for 12.

But Jayawardene was unfazed, bring up his 150 when Panesar spilled a hook shot over the rope for four when he should have held the catch,

Things went from bad to worse for England's worst fielder, with a skier duly juggled it to the floor.

England would have taken a total of 289 for eight at the start of play, but they will know they were set for much better.

MAIDEN TEST WICKET ... Samit Patel

pages.subdeck: BROLLY BAD LUCK ... Lew takes shelter in Sepang
pages.headline: It's the pits
pages.teaser: HAMILTON saw his chances of winning a rain-hit Malaysia GP flushed down the drain
pages.byline: From BEN HUNT in Kuala Lumpur
pages.articlebody:
LEWIS HAMILTON saw his chances of winning the rain-hit Malaysian Grand Prix flushed down the drain.

The McLaren driver started on pole after a brilliant qualifying session and was leading the race in Sepang until the heavens opened.

The rain forced a 51-minute delay but it was an unfortunate pitstop on lap 14 which dampened his day.

Hamilton, 27, was forced to wait for Ferrari's Felipe Massa as the pit lane became congested due to tyre changes, which allowed eventual winner Fernando Alonso to move ahead.

Hamilton said: "We were unfortunate. We didn't make the right calls at the right time and lost a bit of ground there.

"We lost quite a lot of time through a couple of the pit stops. I don't know what problems we had but I seemed to be sitting there for quite some time."

When Hamilton returned to the track he did not have the pace to catch either Alonso or Sergio Perez, who finished second, and he had to settle for third place.

However, he was still pleased to score points, which cannot be said of team-mate Jenson Button, whose accident with Narain Karthikeyan left him in 14th.

Hamilton added: "I wouldn't say I was happy with third but it's really just due to the conditions.

"Those two guys in front did a better job and I was just trying to keep the car on the track."

The biggest winner from the rain was Perez, 22, who started the race on wet tyres, which proved to be a masterstroke. The Sauber driver cut through the field and worked his way up to second behind Ferrari's Alonso.

However, just as he was beginning to turn the screw, he ran too wide allowing Alonso to pull clear.

Afterwards, there were claims Sauber had deliberately allowed Ferrari to win because they are powered by Ferrari engines.

The conspiracy grew after Perez's engineer was heard to tell Perez "we need the position".

But Sauber chief Peter Sauber insisted: "He meant we needed the result. It's a misunderstanding."

When pressed on whether Perez had been told not to push Alonso, Sauber said: "No. We told him 'be careful, we need the result'."

Perez has been linked with replacing Massa at Ferrari.

Champ Sebastian Vettel had a tyre blow-out and was 11th while Red Bull team-mate Mark Webber took a second successive fourth.

For a full listing of the results from the Malaysian Grand Prix and the Driver and Constructor standings, go to our F1 Race Centre.

article.caption: Button: I blew it
Alonso: Winning in Malaysia is a big surprise
Fernando Alonso beats driving rain to win Malaysian Grand Prix

pages.subdeck: UP AND RUNNING ... Papiss Cisse celebrates his opener
pages.headline: West Brom 1 Newcastle 3
pages.teaser: PAPISS CISSE and Hatem Ben Arfa tore West Brom apart at The Hawthorns
pages.articlebody:
ALAN PARDEW'S Magpies clocked up half a century of points for the season to draw level with Chelsea.

But it is Harry Redknapp who will feel the Toon Army breathing down his neck this morning as Newcastle pulled to within five points of Spurs  and a coveted Champions League place.

Papiss Cisse struck twice either side of a stunning Hatem Ben Arfa goal to bury the Baggies, way before Shane Long grabbed a consolation after the break.

Now it will be Pardew  not big-spending Kenny Dalglish  who will be eyeing the Champions League when Liverpool are in Toon this coming Sunday, with Andy Carroll in tow.

Few would have predicted that scenario when Dalglish splashed out £35million to take the pony-tailed Geordie off Pardew's hands.

On this evidence, the Newcastle manager has invested his board's dosh much more shrewdly as his team continue to look the part.

Newcastle actually resembled a crew of council workers yesterday with their high-vis tangerine day-glow away shirts.

Yet West Brom still failed to spot the Tangerine Task Force heading their way.

The Geordie lads clocked in at 4pm.

By 4.12pm, they had already dismantled Roy Hodgson's side, stripped away the few working parts and were 2-0 up.

By 4.34pm, Pardew's boys had knocked in a third, the tools were back in the bag and they were looking forward to a cuppa.

They spent the rest of the afternoon with the sun on their backs, just doing enough to keep the pacing gaffer off their case.

Sure, they conceded a daft goal at the start of the second half, due to a lack of communication.

But overall they more than earned their bonus.

West Brom battled gamely and ended the match with 10 men after James Morrison hobbled off.

However, with or without the Scotland midfielder, they were never going to recover from their disastrous start.

Keeper Ben Foster had already been called on to flick a Demba Ba shot over the bar before Newcastle took a sixth-minute lead.

Jonas Gutierrez stabbed a pass through the Baggies defence to Ben Arfa, who was lurking on the left side of the box.

The former Marseille midfielder's sweeping low cross took out Foster and his defenders.

Demba Ba missed the tantalising centre at full stretch but his striking sidekick Cisse was on his shoulder, waiting to stroke the ball into the empty net with one swipe of his left foot.

Baggies threw themselves forward and pretty much played into Newcastle's hands as Pardew's men picked them off on the counter.

Toon's second, after 12 minutes, was a thing of beauty with Ben Arfa involved throughout. Newcastle swept from one end of the park to the other in no time at all.

Fabricio Coloccini headed clear to Ben Arfa who played a one-two with Danny Guthrie before haring off into space.

As Newcastle fanned out like the Red Arrows  well, tangerine arrows  Ben Arfa combined with Cisse, drove at Jonas Olsson and cut inside his man.

The Frenchman then curled a left-footer beyond Foster from the edge of the box. It was a sublime moment from the midfield 'artiste'.Yohan Cabaye then shot wide from 20 yards before Newcastle added a third on 34 minutes.

Again their movement was a joy to behold as Ben Arfa combined with Ba on the left.

Newcastle top scorer Ba drew in the Baggies defenders before producing a cute backheel to set Ben Arfa free on the wing.

The French ace centred again and Cisse retraced his footsteps to score for a second time.

Cisse then got to his knees, kissed the turf and said a prayer in thanks to a higher power. Yes, Ben Arfa was THAT good. To his credit, Hodgson did not hang about, bringing on Chris Brunt and Shane Long for Jerome Thomas and Keith Andrews at half-time.

Newcastle's change was enforced as Coloccini suffered a hamstring injury which will keep him out of the Liverpool game and probably several others.

But Toon almost went four up just four minutes after the break when Baggies centre-back Gareth McAuley failed to cut out a through ball and Cisse scampered clear.

Foster denied the Senegalese striker a hat-trick with a stunning block with his left arm. West Brom were throwing caution to the wind and it paid off when they pulled one back after 52 minutes.

Youssouf Mulumbu's pass in behind the defence was chased down and Tim Krul and Mike Williamson got their wires crossed.

The defender headed past his on-rushing keeper and sub Long nipped in to gratefully supply the easy finishing touch.

Krul partly atoned for his error when he beat out Peter Odemwingie's stinging effort minutes later as the Baggies sweated in the sun.

But all the sunshine moments were coming from the visitors and Ben Arfa forced Foster into another save with a low shot which the keeper pushed away at full stretch.

Cisse was seen leaving the field on a stretcher but the Toon Army will be pleased to know it was just a bit of cramp.

Morrison hobbled off with a knee injury to leave West Brom with just 10 men on the park.

The game was already gone  but for Newcastle, the season could just be hotting up.

DREAM TEAM

STAR MAN  HATEM BEN ARFA (NEWCASTLE)

WEST BROM: Foster 7, Jones 5, McAuley 5, Olsson 5, Ridgewell 5, Morrison 6, Andrews 4 (Long 6), Mulumbu 5 (Scharner 5), Thomas 4 (Brunt 6), Odemwingie 5, Fortune 6. Subs not used: Daniels, Shorey, Dawson, Cox.

NEWCASTLE: Krul 6, Simpson 7, Williamson 6, Coloccini 7 (Santon 6), Perch 7, Ben Arfa 9 (Shola Ameobi 6), Guthrie 7, Cabaye 8, Gutierrez 8, Cisse 8 (Ferguson 5), Ba 8. Subs not used: Elliot, Abeid, Gosling, Vuckic. Booked: Williamson.

REF: C Foy 7

pages.subdeck: BACKING ... Arsene Wenger likes the way Arsenal's defenders play out from the back
pages.headline: Arsene's case for defence
pages.teaser: ARSENE WENGER reckons his much-maligned defence is behind Arsenal's recent run
pages.articlebody:
ARSENE WENGER reckons his much-maligned defence is behind Arsenal's recent resurgence.

Gunners have roared past North London rivals Tottenham into third place after seven straight Premier League wins.

That is an amazing turnaround after Wenger was taking flak from all sides as Arsenal's form slumped in the first half of the season.

He said: "When we were not winning games I did not feel we played as badly as people said.

"We have gained a lot of confidence in our play out from the back and that makes a massive difference."

"The defenders who play out from the back give us a security now and that allows the team to be much more confident."

Saturday's 3-0 win over Aston Villa took Arsenal three points clear of Spurs and eight ahead of fifth-placed Chelsea in the race for Champions League spots.

But after being written off as top-four contenders earlier in the season, Wenger is taking nothing for granted yet.

The Frenchman said: "It is always very difficult in our game because you multiply the positive vibes by 25 players and also the negative vibes by 25.

"When you are in a bad period it is very hard to get out of it, when you are in a good period you need to keep your urgency.

"The fact we are close to the end of the season means every game is now a cup final."

pages.subdeck: CISSE FIT ... Fernandes laid in Djibril after his red card
pages.headline: Tony blasts Cisse
pages.teaser: FUMING Fernandes was "p***ed off" after Cisse's red card in Sunderland defeat
pages.articlebody:
TONY FERNANDES has ripped into Djibril Cisse.

The QPR chairman lost his cool after the striker was sent off in the 3-1 defeat at Sunderland  his second red card since joining the club in January.

Fernandes raged on Twitter: "This is the first time I am genuinely p***ed off. We have to bloody keep 11 players on the pitch.

"Boy, do we make it difficult. We have eight games left, four at home, which are winnable.

"It is up to the players now  we've done all we can. The manager can do nothing if players keep getting booked and sent off."

QPR are a point away from safety but Fernandes is backing boss Mark Hughes.

He added: "Mark is the right guy and has my support. Red cards are nothing to do with luck  very frustrating."

article.caption: Sparky eyes the big guns
Barton rap
Sunderland 3 QPR 1

pages.subdeck: VIVE LA FRANCE ... Joe Cole is enjoying his time at Lille
pages.headline: Billionaire wants a Lille piece of the action
pages.teaser: JOE COLE'S Lille are rumoured to be the target of an unnamed Arab billionaire
pages.articlebody:
JOE COLE'S Lille are rumoured to be the target of an unnamed Arab billionaire with links to Manchester City's owners.

Lille supremo Michel Seydoux is reportedly in talks with mega-rich investors from the United Arab Emirates.

They are said to be "friends" of City's Abu Dhabi-based owner Sheikh Mansour bin Zayed Al Nahyan, a member of the UAE's ruling family.

Last summer, Qatari billionaires bought Paris St Germain. This week Lyon president Jean-Michel Aulas was also said to be in Dubai to discuss the sale of his club  or part of it.

Arab network Al Jazeera  part of the same group as PSG's owners  have bought the TV rights for Ligue 1.

So why all the fuss about France? Simple  it is much cheaper than the Premier League to buy clubs and to challenge for silverware, as well as attract top names.

Before buying PSG, Qatar Sports Investments looked at Manchester United but were put off by the £1BILLION cost.

PSG, a glamorous club based in the French capital, cost 'just' £40m.

A top source told me: "In their first season at Paris, QSI invested £80m to bring in stars like Javier Pastore. Paris are top of Ligue 1 and favourites for the title.

"City owner Sheikh Al Mansour has spent over £1bn in transfers and wages. It took three years to win the FA Cup and get into the Champions League.

"It took four years to challenge for the title and they still seem to be falling short.

"It is much cheaper in France. Also if you pay so little compared to buying an English club, you have massive sums available for players and wages."

Lille's Belgian superstar Eden Hazard tops the list of City's summer targets and only last week boss Roberto Mancini went to watch him against Valenciennes.

Buying Lille would cost about as much as Hazard  between £30m and £40m.

Lille's new state-of-the-art stadium, which cost £260m and holds 50,000, will open in the summer.

It was a public-private partnership and Lille, where England ace Cole is spending the season on loan from Liverpool, will pay an annual rent of £6m for 31 years.

It will then be owed by the municipality but until then Lille will have full rights to maximize their profits from the venue.

This will make a takeover very attractive.

And with so much oil money being pumped into the French top flight, interest is sure to rise.

They will get the coverage in key markets from Al Jazeera.

The French could soon rival the Premier League and La Liga for the huge revenues from international TV rights and merchandising sales.

He's the Mess-iah

LIONEL MESSI set a new scoring record for Barcelona on Saturday.

His goal in the 2-0 win at Mallorca meant he has 35 League goals for the season  one more than the club's previous best set by Brazil star Ronaldo under Sir Bobby Robson in 1996-7.

But Cristiano Ronaldo, 27, struck twice as Real Madrid thrashed Real Sociedad 5-1 to stay level with Messi at the top of this season's League scoring charts.

In all competitions, Messi has 49 goals in this campaign with Ronaldo on 44.

Messi, 24, has lifted 18 trophies. Ronaldo has won 10. In 11 Clasicos since Ronaldo joined Madrid, Messi (above) has seven wins to Ronaldo's one.

But who is the greatest? Here is Arsenal boss Arsene Wenger's verdict: "Messi is certainly the greatest for the moment.

"He has pace, ball control, speed of thought, efficiency and humility. It's rare that a player has such talent and it does not make him arrogant.

"Cristiano Ronaldo is, I wouldn't say in the shadow of Messi, but he must in some way want to get in front of Messi.

"He has the potential to do it. He's a force of nature."

article.caption: Harry could lead us to Euro glory  unlike Fab
City eye Eden
Hazard lights up at Fergie scouting
Harry lines up £30m Hazard

pages.subdeck: DREAD ... Antonio Valencia
pages.headline: Valencia dreading Tevez winner
pages.teaser: MANCHESTER UNITED winger reckons Argentine wantaway is a threat for juggernaut clash
pages.articlebody:
ANTONIO VALENCIA fears the prospect of rivals City winning the Manchester derby  and Carlos Tevez scoring the deciding goal.

It is the horror scenario for the red half of a city that is already counting the days to April 30.

That is when the teams lock horns in the season's biggest clash at the Etihad and when the Premier League title will probably be decided.

Like Tevez for City, Valencia has just returned to the United team  and with a similar impact.

His goal at Wolves eight days ago after more injury woes was a stormer, while Tevez's assist for Samir Nasri helped beat Chelsea on Wednesday following his long break.

Valencia continues his comeback against Fulham tonight and is convinced United will win their 20th title. But he cannot stand the thought of Tevez spoiling the party.

He said: "If Carlos plays against us, I'm sure he'll be motivated. He's an excellent player, able to change a match in an instant. What he did against Chelsea was no surprise.

"But for Tevez to score the winner? I hope it doesn't happen.

"And for us to fail and lose the title will bring pain for months. But I'm confident in my team.

"There's a lot of pride in Manchester that our two clubs are the best in England.

"But now we are focused on Fulham because our challenge is to win all our matches and to arrive with an advantage over City on derby day.

"I'm not saying whether that game will decide the title but it's clear the winners will deliver a morale blow to the other club. So I expect a big battle and for us to avenge our 6-1 defeat at Old Trafford."

Valencia, 26, is flying again after last season's horrific broken leg and further injury during the summer's Copa America with Ecuador.

And recently he suffered a troublesome hamstring injury in the Europa League against Ajax.

His excellent performance at Wolves has boss Alex Ferguson purring and Fulham can expect the runaround at Old Trafford.

Fergie said: "Antonio could be very important. His form before he got the injury was outstanding. Now he's back, we hope he stays fit.

"You get two sides to Antonio. He's prepared to work hard, he can tackle, run but he can also beat a man. He's got everything."

Valencia is determined to carry on where he left off and said: "I'm happy to be back. Initially, I feared my latest injury would affect me but this time the situation wasn't so grave.

"Now I dream about helping the team, making the most of my chances.

"It's not easy getting into the first XI at United. That was why I was angered about my last injury.

"I have been working with the physios to advance my recovery and now the key for me is to avoid more injury problems.

"I've a good sensation about the end of season personally  and for the team. Certain blows have affected my career at important moments but I hope these episodes are over and now I think only about playing and winning."

pages.subdeck: IN COMMAND ... Alex Ferguson
pages.headline: Fergie hails his United fighters
pages.teaser: UNITED could move three points clear at the top of the Premier League tonight
pages.articlebody:
ALEX FERGUSON says he has a team of fighters who will not let go of their title.

Manchester United could move three points clear at the top of the Premier League tonight by beating Fulham.

And after a season spent battling injuries and continually chasing rivals City, United will suddenly be in the driving seat.

Boss Fergie said: "I have to congratulate the players on achieving the position we're in because of the injuries we've had. They've shown resilience and we're in the position we are now because of that.

"I was hoping City would drop something but I also knew we really had to perform well to take advantage.

"We went down to London to play Tottenham, Arsenal and Chelsea.

"We should have beaten Chelsea but if you take seven points from nine all in a short space of time, then it's a job well done."

Whatever happens this season, Ferguson is convinced United and City will be fighting for silverware for years.

He added: "What we've got to get used to, and United and City fans too, is there's going to be big games involving us  semi-finals, finals, whatever  for a decade.

"Arsenal, Chelsea and Spurs can also stabilise themselves and have great teams."

pages.subdeck: FEELING THE HEAT ... Roberto Di Matteo
pages.headline: RDM finds it's tough at top
pages.teaser: BLUES manager admits the players are struggling to cope with hectic fixtures list
pages.articlebody:
ROBERTO DI MATTEO admits Chelsea are finding the going tough  but the tough have to get going.

The Blues must raise their game for the first leg of the Champions League quarter-final away to Benfica tomorrow.

Di Matteo said: "We are playing big games every three days and that is taking its toll. Physically and mentally it's very demanding.

"There's not much time to recover and stay fresh. So we will have to see how the players are and put a team together that has the energy to get a result against Benfica."

Boss Di Matteo wants Blues to take inspiration from the last round, when they beat Napoli 4-1 to progress.

He added: "Napoli were a good side, very dangerous. We will prepare for the game very well and we will be ready to play."

The big plus for Chelsea is the form of £7million defender Gary Cahill.

Di Matteo said: "We look much better and solid. We are making it more difficult for the opposition to score."

Blues look Kalou-less

pages.subdeck: VOLLEY GOOD SHOW ... Peter Crouch celebrates
pages.headline: Crouch Stokes fire for England
pages.teaser: POTTERS ace hopes his stunning goal will help him roar into Euro 2012 team
pages.articlebody:
PETER CROUCH hopes his stunning Stoke goal will help him roar into England's Euro 2012 team.

The Potters strike ace rocked Manchester City's title bid with one of the Premier League's greatest goals at the Britannia on Saturday in a 1-1 draw.

Now he is dreaming of pulling on a Three Lions jersey this summer in Poland and Ukraine.

Crouch, 31, has not featured for his country since November 2010  despite scoring in that game against France and firing a staggering 22 goals in just 42 internationals.

Crouch, 31, said: "I knew right from the start when I signed for Stoke that, if I was playing well and scoring goals, I would have a chance of being involved in the England set-up.

"There is a huge competition in the summer. I have been fortunate enough to play in two World Cups and have 42 caps for my country.

"I know if I work hard and play well I'll get a chance and hopefully grab it with both hands."

His goal showed just why he is not just a "big man" as he skilfully flicked the ball up and then twisted to volley over keeper Joe Hart from 25 yards. He said: "I do it every day in training, practice volleying. It is something I've always enjoyed doing.

"When the ball dropped I tried to pop it up and tried the volley technique.

"I do it a lot in practice  it is not something that just happens  but they don't always fly in like that.

"I think that was probably the best one to be honest."

Crouch's strike fired Stoke ahead but Yaya Toure levelled.

He said: "Any team will tell you that at the Britannia this season we are a match for anyone. We have shown it time and again."

article.caption: Is Mancini cracking up?
Stoke City 1 Man City 1

image.caption: VOLLEY GOOD SHOW ... Peter Crouch celebrates

pages.subdeck: POINTING THE FINGER ... Nico Gaitan
pages.headline: Nico raps Drog 'n Torres
pages.teaser: BENFICA star reckons their poor goal returns have made strikers nervous wrecks
pages.articlebody:
BENFICA winger Nico Gaitan claims Didier Drogba and Fernando Torres' goal struggles have turned Chelsea into nervous wrecks.

Gaitan's team take on the Blues at the Stadium of Light in Lisbon tomorrow night.

He believes this is the perfect time to face them after Chelsea drew a blank against top-four rivals Tottenham.

And Gaitan is confident Benfica will claim their second English scalp of this season's Champions League after helping to dump out Manchester United at the group stage.

The Argentina star said: "I think there is an anxiety in Chelsea by the lack of goals from Torres and Drogba.

"We can exploit that and even though it will be difficult to stop them, it is possible and I have confidence we will keep a clean sheet."

Drogba has found the back of the net just three times for Chelsea since the start of the year. Torres' two goals against Leicester in the FA Cup last week were his first since October.

Gaitan added: "Benfica are having a good season in Europe. This is our main strength against Chelsea.

"The squad is convinced we can create chances and we play without fear against anyone."

Like Chelsea, Benfica warmed up for the Stadium of Light clash against the Blues with a goalless draw.

They drew a blank against Olhanense, which knocked them off the top of the Portuguese league.

Luck But Gaitan insisted: "Both teams failed to score this weekend in the domestic leagues but that is just luck.

"It wasn't the Champions League game which caused the 0-0 scores.

"We are very focused in this knockout game because, for us, those are the matches of the year.

"To get into the semi-finals is to fulfil the first part of our European dream.

"The tie is very open and without a clear favourite.

"Chelsea are, of course, strong in Europe but we are not inferior to them."

pages.subdeck: GARAGE GUEST ... Hollywood star Own Wilson gets the F1 lowdown in Caterham's garage
pages.headline: Hollywood goes to Caterham
pages.teaser: INSIDE F1: TOM WEBB reveals there were a few surprises for Caterham in Malaysia, including a visit from film star Owen Wilson
pages.articlebody:
FOR anyone watching at home, the 2012 Malaysian Grand Prix must have been one of the great races.

It had everything.

There was the complete range of weather conditions and drivers used every ounce of talent at their disposal just to keep the cars on track.

There were closely fought battles up and down the pecking order.

Fernando Alonso's God-given skills saw him drag a machine to victory when it probably did not deserve to finish in the top 10.

And there was also a first Formula One top-three finish for Sergio Perez  the man who may well be Alonso's next team-mate at Ferrari.

For Caterham F1 Team it was also a dramatic race.

We had a two-car pitstop to put both cars on full wet tyres at the same time when the safety car came out.

We also had a change of nose for Heikki Kovalainen after he had an excursion off-track and hit a bollard.

And Vitaly Petrov was fighting with a Ferrari, a McLaren and a Toro Rosso for much of the race.

All of this was played out in the stifling heat that the Malaysian GP is renowned for.

On the team timetable in the garage the race team co-ordinator Graham Watson  Smudge to everyone who knows him  had written in large letters: "KEEP DRINKING WATER".

As if the boys in the garage needed any reminding.

Staying hydrated is the key to being able to perform in an environment like Malaysia.

It is the hottest race of the year, along with Singapore, and it is the humidity that really hits hard.

Heikki and Vitaly have a hydration plan that starts as soon as they arrive in Malaysia five days before the race.

They build up their intake of liquids over the week until race day when they can consume up to seven litres of water, electrolytes and sports drinks.

That helps them balance out the three to four kilograms of weight they will lose in the car in the longest race of the season.

The mechanics are obviously not under the same degree of physical stress as the drivers.

But having to don fireproof overalls three hours before the race on Sunday and working in a garage that reached 40°C in 2012, with humidity peaking at 84 per cent, puts a huge physical strain on already stressed capabilities.

Despite this testing environment everyone just gets on with it.

There is no time to worry about being soaked to the skin after the run back to the garage from the grid and the humour levels and positivity stay as high as ever.

The mood is always boosted when a famous face appears in the garage and this year it was Hollywood superstar Owen Wilson.

He caused a tangible ripple of excitement as he was shown around our garage by team principal Tony Fernandes just under an hour before the race was due to start.

Tony handed over to team manager Graham Watson to explain the detail of a 2012 F1 steering wheel to the Wedding Crashers star.

Vitaly's race engineer Gianluca Pisanello then talked him through the timetable his car crew was working to with under an hour until lights out.

Meanwhile, word was spreading across the paddock that the biggest celebrity at the race was in our garage.

Suddenly, we were inundated with TV cameras and photographers, all desperate for a shot that would fill Monday's back pages or an interview that adds to the pre-race build up for the fans at home.

Oscar winner Adrien Brody, in town with his friend Owen on a movie shoot, also appeared and the media frenzy around what was already an incredibly busy pit intensified.

All of this mayhem was going on but it did not distract the team from the job in hand.

The cars were still being fired up, tyre pressures were being checked and pitstop equipment was examined to make sure it would work as planned at the critical moment.

And the most calm people in the frenzy were the boys in green and yellow.

This is F1 in a nutshell.

We go around the world to race the most incredible machines in incredibly demanding environments.

Hundreds of millions of people watch every single race and the biggest stars on the planet drop by because it is up there with the Oscars for global attention.

But at the heart of it are the teams  the men and women who make the show happen  and even when they have the surreal experience of looking up and seeing Hollywood royalty inspecting their work, they just get on with it.

F1 is a world of contrasts and that is what makes it what it is.

image.caption: GARAGE GUEST ... Hollywood star Own Wilson gets the F1 lowdown in Caterham's garage
FLUID THINKING ... Heikki Kovalainen has water bottle to hand while talking with Lewis Hamilton
HEAD CASE... Caterham truckie Tubbsie's solution for keeping cool in Malaysia
SLIDE RULE ... Caterham's Vitaly Petrov battles the conditions in Malaysia

pages.subdeck: IT'S THE RUBBER THE GREEN ... tyre woes have hit Schuey
pages.headline: Tyred of it
pages.teaser: RUBBER troubles have ruined the first two Grands Prix of Mercedes pair's season
pages.articlebody:
STRUGGLING Mercedes pair Michael Schumacher and Nico Rosberg are mystified over the tyre troubles that have ruined their first two Grands Prix.

Rosberg in particular has gone backwards in the races after impressive qualifying sessions.

And Schuey has been unable to capitalise on Merc's strong straightline speed.

Baffled Rosberg revealed that while high tyre degradation was a huge problem in Australia, the issues he faced in Malaysia were completely different.

He said: "It is strange we are so strong in qualifying but then struggling in the race.

"In qualifying with the car we have we can fight for the front row but in the race we cannot match that.

"In Malaysia, everything was going well strategy-wise. I was P4 after the red flag and pitstop, and from then on I thought I could do something good. But then I started going backwards, big time.

"My first set of intermediate tyres felt completely destroyed. But my pit crew told me they were brand new still. It was strange.

"From then on, it was getting worse and worse. Going on to slicks was a bit of a highlight as I managed to beat Jenson, which was nice. But fighting for 13th place is not worth mentioning."

Rosberg admitted Mercedes face "a lot of work" to get to grips with the problem.

He said: "It is going to take some thorough analysis. But we have enough time before China so I hope we can improve.

"I am looking forward to China to finally getting a better result. My season starts there, more or less."

image.caption: IT'S THE RUBBER THE GREEN ... tyre woes have hit Schuey

article.caption: Perez cools Ferrari talk

pages.subdeck: MOVING MOMENT ... 'Spiderman' Castroneves celebrates by Wheldon street sign
pages.headline: Winner Helio's salute to Dan
pages.teaser: HELIO CASTRONEVERS won the season's first IndyCar race and paid an emotional tribute to tragic Dan Wheldon
pages.articlebody:
HOW'S this for a fitting tribute?

Helio Castroneves, winner of the season's first IndyCar race, performs his trademark "Spiderman" salute by climbing the circuit's catch fencing.

But he makes sure he does it at the sign of the new street named after Dan Wheldon in the tragic Brit's adopted home city of St Petersburg.

Deeply religious Brazilian Castroneves also said a prayer for Dan  killed in the IndyCar series' finale last year  as he leaped down from the fence on the Florida street circuit's Turn 10.

He said: "You can never question God's mysteries.

"And today I ended up stopping my car at Turn 10. Honestly I did not plan it. It was just the way it happened.

"And there was the sign 'Dan Wheldon Way'. For me, and for all of us, the drivers and the fans, we certainly missed not having him here.

"But we've got to remember him the way he lived and continue to pray for his family."

He added: "As soon as I got there, you know, I felt very touched seeing Dan's name.

"We still hurt but we have to keep moving on. I did think about my family as well. That's why there was a little more emotion."

Castroneves won after making a daring pass on series favourite Scott Dixon around the outside of Turn 1 on Lap 73.

The Penske Racing driver eventually beat Kiwi Dixon by 5.5secs, helping him to forget a miserable 2011 season.

The triumph also marked a return to the winner's circle for Chevrolet, who provided Castroneves' engine.

The race was the first for IndyCar's new Dallara DW12 cars that take their model name from Wheldon, the company's test driver last year.

Yorkshire's finest Justin Wilson finished tenth with fellow Brit and reigning champ Dario Franchitti 13th.

Former Formula One veteran Rubens Barrichello finished 17th in his first IndyCar race after a late pit stop dropped him four places.
